author: By Chris Vognar
title: ‘The Fortress’: A Norwegian Export About the Danger of Closed Borders
description: Both sociopolitical thriller and parable, this Viaplay series presents a future that can feel uncomfortably plausible.
content: In “The Fortress,” a new series about pandemic, isolationism and government corruption, something is rotten in the state of Norway. The year is 2037, and the country has spent the last decade cut off from the rest of the world, behind a wall of its own making. When a deadly virus sweeps through the land, the prime minister blames refugees for bringing the illness to an insulated paradise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: America’s Unstable Politics
description: A remarkable day for both Donald Trump and President Biden highlights our new era of political uncertainty.
content: American politics was more stable for the past half-century than it had been for most of the country’s history. Incumbent presidents often won re-election. No major political figure was assassinated. The two parties’ basic ideologies and coalitions remained similar.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lev Grossman on the Enduring Story of King Arthur
description: The novelist discusses his latest book, “The Bright Sword,” in which Arthur has died but Excalibur lives on with a band of misfit knights.
content: You may know Lev Grossman for his best-selling Magicians trilogy of fantasy novels, which were adapted into a TV show also called “The Magicians” and which were “like ‘The Secret History’ crossed with ‘Harry Potter’” and Narnia, in the words of Edan Lepucki, who reviewed the final book in the series for us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Donald Trump Promised a Softer Image. He Delivered Hulkamania.
description: The last night of the Republican National Convention featured glimpses of a more sober tone — and a whole lot of testosterone.
content: Who is Donald J. Trump?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I Keep the Family Tree — And I’m Flummoxed About Whom to Include.
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on genealogy, record-keeping and notions of relation.
content: I have taken over keeping my family tree. I am fortunate that this tree dates to the late 1700s. It means a large family, in many countries, with four generations of relatives still alive, some of whom I have never met or don’t know well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haiyun Jiang
title: The Candidate
description: A single image captures supporters of former President Donald J. Trump rallying around him after his attempted assassination.
content: A sea of Republicans greeted former President Donald J. Trump with cheers and thunderous applause as he appeared at the Republican National Convention this week in Milwaukee, just days after his attempted assassination. He responded by pumping his fist in the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Jill Cowan
title: Hospitals Cancel Nonessential Surgeries After Global Technology Outage
description: Hospital systems across the country reported I.T. disruptions. A spokesman for Kaiser Permanente called the situation “unprecedented.”
content: Hospitals and health care providers across the United States told patients on Friday morning that a global technology outage had downed some information technology systems, resulting in canceled surgeries and other procedures, though the hospitals emphasized that emergency departments remained open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include Swedish evildoers, South Korean warrior-ghosts and a devil stalking the American frontier.
content: Andrea Riseborough and Stellan Skarsgard star in Ran Huang’s devastating feature debut. It’s a psychodrama inspired by Thomas Quick, who confessed to more than 30 murders in the 1990s while detained in a Swedish mental institution, only to later admit that he fabricated them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Simon Johnson, Shane Goldmacher, Peter Baker, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Global IT Outage Wreaks Havoc, and Trump Makes Divisive Speech
description: Plus, comedy legend Bob Newhart dies.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Nguyen Phu Trong, Powerful Vietnamese Leader, Is Dead at 80
description: Known for his “blazing furnace” anticorruption campaign, Mr. Trong consolidated power in one of the world’s few remaining Communist dictatorships.
content: Nguyen Phu Trong, the hard-line general secretary of Vietnam’s Communist Party, who presided over his country’s economic and geopolitical transformation and reshaped its leadership with his “blazing furnace” anticorruption campaign, died on Friday in Hanoi. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: A Tip Sheet to Help Decipher American Politics
description: With the presidential campaign in a stretch of discord and profound uncertainty, here are a few pieces that provide understanding and context.
content: I had just passed through metal detectors at the State Department’s headquarters in Washington, D.C., on Monday when I heard one of the security guards tell a colleague that the man who tried to assassinate former President Trump was an “antifa extremist.” It was a baseless claim, drawn from social media posts that falsely identified an Italian sports journalist as the shooter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Austyn Gaffney
title: Counting the Costs of a Global IT Outage
description: A “historic” tech failure alarmed investors, after a security update caused problems for Microsoft devices and services, and took down businesses worldwide.
content: Grounded flights, emergency services unreachable, payment systems not functioning — the world is assessing the damage caused by a cascade of IT outages that is spooking investors and grinding many businesses and government services to a halt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant and Cade Metz
title: The Push to Develop Generative A.I. Without All the Lawsuits
description: Companies like Getty have begun developing A.I. models with their own data, part of a broader push to build artificial intelligence with licensed content.
content: Companies like Google and OpenAI built their artificial intelligence chatbots and image generators by gobbling content from the web, spurring legal fights over copyright claims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Ocasio-Cortez Warns of ‘Enormous Peril’ if Democrats Push Biden Aside
description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez said the idea of having an open Democratic convention where candidates would compete for the nomination was “crazy.”
content: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York urged Democrats to reconsider their efforts to replace President Biden as their nominee, warning that members of her party were discounting his electoral strengths and hurtling ahead without a clear succession plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: A Magic Phrase to Defeat Nosy Questions
description: Here’s how to shut down “predatory curiosity.”
content: I have one kid. I am happy with one kid. Yet, over the years, dozens of people have asked if I’m ever going to “give her a sibling.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Details Assassination Attempt in Convention Speech
description: Donald Trump said he had “God on my side” during the shooting at his rally on Saturday — and called on Americans to put aside the divisions he has often stoked to restore him to the White House in November.
content: Five days after a gunman tried to assassinate him at a political rally, former President Donald J. Trump on Thursday night described his personal experience of the shooting as he formally accepted the Republican Party’s presidential nomination and called on Americans to see in him a unifier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Fallon Finds Bright Side of Biden Testing Positive for Covid
description: “It’s the first positive news he’s had in months,” Fallon said on Thursday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Michael Gold
title: Melania and Ivanka Trump Fill Out the Family Portrait, but Not Barron
description: After staying largely out of sight, the former president’s wife and his eldest daughter joined him as he accepted the Republican nomination. But his youngest son did not.
content: The tableau of Trump family unity was nearly complete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Lakin
title: These Sculptures Changed What Art Could Be, Then Changed Themselves
description: Eva Hesse’s latex and fiberglass pieces from the late 1960s have been reunited from five institutions. Their rapid deterioration makes their future uncertain — which may be their best quality.
content: Eva Hesse, the German American artist, wanted her work to look “ucky,” and accordingly, many of her sculptures can make your skin crawl. They behave like skin themselves: irregular in texture, their craggy folds suggesting, unnervingly, something alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: This Summer’s Sleeper TV Hit: ‘Your Honor’
description: Once again, a show with little following has become hugely popular once it starts streaming on Netflix.
content: Over a decade ago, “Breaking Bad,” the crime drama starring Bryan Cranston, catapulted from a basic cable show with so-so ratings to a big hit after Netflix started streaming it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: Landlords Used Software to Set Rents. Then Came the Lawsuits.
description: Antitrust cases contend that use of RealPage’s algorithm, which lets property owners share private data, amounts to collusion.
content: Imagine a system that lets big landlords in your city work together to raise rents, using detailed, otherwise-private information about what their competitors are charging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Harvey Weinstein’s Latest Sexual Assault Trial Set to Start in November
description: Manhattan prosecutors are proceeding with new charges against the disgraced movie mogul after his previous conviction was overturned.
content: A Manhattan judge on Friday set Nov. 12 as the tentative date for the start of jury selection in a new sexual assault case against the disgraced Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein, whose 2020 sex-crimes conviction in New York was overturned in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: JD Vance and the Tech-Trad Alliance
description: How Silicon Valley and religious conservatism might converge.
content: Just over seven months ago, the talented pseudonymous writer Trace Woodgrains wrote an essay announcing the Republican Party’s doom — not the doom of electoral irrelevance, since the G.O.P. clearly isn’t going anywhere, but the doom of being unable to find enough talented people to actually carry out its agenda, shape the culture or really govern the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Ben Sasse Will Step Down as President of University of Florida
description: The former senator from Nebraska cited the health of his wife, who has been diagnosed with epilepsy.
content: Ben Sasse, the president of the University of Florida and a former Republican senator from Nebraska, announced Thursday that he was resigning his position so he could dedicate more time and attention to his ailing wife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer and Lisa Lerer
title: Call With Harris Struggles to Reassure Major Democratic Donors
description: On a call, Vice President Kamala Harris told about 300 donors that there was little to worry about. Several listeners said they found the call to have little value.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris tried to buck up the Democratic Party’s biggest donors on Friday, telling about 300 of them that there was little to worry about in President Biden’s campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: Will a Movie Faking the Moon Landing Propel a Debunked Conspiracy Theory?
description: The screenwriters of “Fly Me to the Moon” say they emphasized the facts of the Apollo 11 landing, but experts worry that clips can be misused.
content: The new Scarlett Johansson-Channing Tatum vehicle “Fly Me to the Moon” uses a long-debunked conspiracy theory as the jumping-off point for a space-race romantic comedy. At the end of the 1960s, a wary NASA recognizes the need for better public relations during the Vietnam War. The resulting campaign leads to a faked version of the Apollo 11 mission being shot on a sound stage even as the real mission is unfolding. Shenanigans, and romance, ensue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Find Me Falling’ Review: A Romance With an Edge
description: Harry Connick Jr. stars as a cranky rocker who returns to Cyprus, the home of the love who inspired a signature hit.
content: When John Allman retreats to a shack on the coast of Cyprus in “Find Me Falling,” he’s already glum. The aging rocker, portrayed by Harry Connick Jr., marches out of his new refuge with indignation and barks at a man standing on the cliff’s edge looking out at the sea. Then the man steps into the air and is gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Emily Cochrane
title: A Small Town Gives a Solemn Farewell to Man Killed at a Trump Rally
description: Corey Comperatore died shielding his family when a gunman opened fire on the stage where the former president was speaking to supporters in Butler, Pa.
content: One by one on Friday morning, people began to gather along the winding roads and corn fields to plant American flags, spread out their blankets and wait for the fire trucks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Has A.I. Affected the Way You Date Online? We Want to Know.
description: The Times is looking for readers who are using generative A.I. services like ChatGPT to craft messages for dating — or who have been on the receiving end of such messages.
content: The New York Times is looking at the ways artificial intelligence is assisting, disrupting and generally changing the way we date. Specifically, we’re curious to see how A.I. might affect the way you flirt online and in text messages. We’d love to hear from you or someone you know about your experience with generative A.I. services as it relates to your love life to potentially include in a coming article.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: What’s Left for France’s Left?
description: Two weeks ago a coalition of left-wing parties came first in the legislative elections. Now some wonder whether it will have any power at all.
content: When a left-wing coalition came first this month in France’s parliamentary elections and upended a predicted victory for the far right, supporters filled the streets. Some cried, some danced. “The left has awakened,” a supporter said. “We’ve shown that something else is possible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur, Kate Conger and Sheera Frenkel
title: Chaos and Confusion: Tech Outage Causes Disruptions Worldwide
description: Airlines, hospitals and people’s computers were affected after CrowdStrike, a cybersecurity company, sent out a flawed software update.
content: Airlines grounded flights. Operators of 911 lines could not respond to emergencies. Hospitals canceled surgeries. Retailers closed for the day. And the actions all traced back to a batch of bad computer code.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Senator Jon Tester, Facing Tough Re-Election Fight, Urges Biden to Drop Out
description: Mr. Tester, the Democratic incumbent in heavily Republican Montana, is now the second sitting senator to publicly call on President Biden to end his re-election campaign.
content: Senator Jon Tester of Montana called on President Biden to drop his campaign for re-election on Thursday night, becoming the second sitting Democratic senator to publicly join the effort to push Mr. Biden out of the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Corporate Workers Get a Snow Day in July Because of Outage
description: “Happy international blue screen day.”
content: It’s a sensation familiar to anyone who has seen the 1986 movie “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off”: You wake up and find yourself with an unexpected day of freedom. And today, people didn’t even have to fake a fever or dodge a tempestuous school principal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: ‘One of the Truly Awful and Self-Indulgent Performances of Our Time’: The Best and Worst Moments From Night 4 of the Convention
description: Times Opinion writers assess Night 4 of the Republican convention, which included speeches from Hulk Hogan, Mike Pompeo and Donald Trump.
content: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for Night 4 of the Republican National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rate the evening on a scale of 0 to 10: 0 means the night was a disaster for Donald Trump; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which culminated in Trump’s acceptance speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: ‘Hello, Dolly!’ Review: Imelda Staunton Has the Wow, Wow, Wow Factor
description: The veteran British actress shines in a new revival that is the musical theater highlight of the West End summer.
content: Love affairs in the theater take different forms — between characters onstage, of course, but also between a performer and the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: You Like Wine? Try Planting a Vineyard at Home.
description: People plant grapevines in their backyards to get a rural aesthetic or for the love of wine itself, or even just for the science of it all.
content: Craig Lemoine had a concrete slab in his backyard and he didn’t know what to do with it. “It was very sad,” he said. “I like everything to be green and lush.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones and Reto Sterchi
title: In ‘Twisters,’ Storm Chasers Want to Disrupt a Tornado. Is That Possible?
description: The original ‘Twister’ ushered in a new era of fascination with tornadoes. Its follow-up may have even bigger ambitions.
content: Sean Waugh holds a laptop with green, red and yellow weather radar looping as his driver rumbles down an Oklahoma highway in their government-issued truck. The vehicle holds 50 gallons of fuel, so they can chase storms all day. A rectangular cage with metal mesh covers the truck in an attempt to protect the team from hail. Hanging off the front of the hail cage are weather instruments that look like the horn of a rhinoceros charging into a storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai, Jonathan Wolfe and Jill Cowan
title: 911 Systems Disrupted in at Least 3 States
description: Emergency call lines were operating in most major cities, but the authorities in Oregon, Alaska and Arizona said some of their systems had been hit by the outage.
content: Emergency call systems in at least three states were hit by the widespread CrowdStrike technology outage, although most major U.S. cities avoided problems overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Seattle Police Officer Fired Over ‘Cruel Comments’ About Pedestrian’s Death
description: The officer, Daniel Auderer, was heard laughing as he discussed Jaahnavi Kandula, who was struck and killed by a speeding police S.U.V. driven by another Seattle officer.
content: A Seattle police officer was fired on Wednesday for his “cruel comments” and “callous laughter” about a pedestrian who was struck and killed by a police vehicle last year, the city’s interim police chief said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Janfaza
title: The Voices Young Conservatives Are Listening to Online
description: Thirty people ages 18 to 30 said they sought out individuals with strong opinions, especially those they see as outside the mainstream media.
content: By the time that former President Donald J. Trump joined TikTok in June, conservative content was flourishing on the social media platform, known for its grip on young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bonnie Tsui
title: Oh, the Ordinary Places You’ll Go!
description: For some travelers, the big draw in a destination is not a hot new restaurant or high-end hotel. It’s the grocery store, swimming pool or kitchenware shop, where they can dip into the stream of local life.
content: You could say that I have a public pool habit when I travel. From Reykjavík and Sydney to Phoenix and Palm Springs, Calif., it’s how I eavesdrop on and observe everyday life, wherever I am. Early one morning last summer in Tokyo, I entered the lobby of a sports complex in the Shimokitazawa neighborhood, joined the orderly queue of seniors, and enthusiastically pantomimed my way to a day pass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A ‘Jedi of Emotion’ Taught Him a New Language
description: Matthew Eubank, great at writing down his feelings, learned how to talk about them after meeting Kara Loewentheil, a life coach, podcaster and author.
content: It’s second nature for Kara Ann Loewentheil to get her feelings out in the open and deal with them. Matthew Scott Eubank, who called her “a Jedi of emotion,” found the idea terrifying at first, but then began “to trust the system.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: How a School Bus Electrified a Reporter’s Hometown
description: Dionne Searcey traveled to Wymore, Neb., where she grew up, to learn about some residents’ resistance to a new battery-powered bus.
content: Many of my friends have abandoned Facebook. My three teenagers never even signed up for it. I, however, check Facebook almost every day. It helps me stay in touch with friends and family in my hometown, Wymore, Neb., a rural community of about 1,300. That’s how I learned that the school district there was getting a free, brand-new bus powered not by gas but by electricity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Bob Newhart Holds Up
description: He basically invented the stand-up special in 1960 and continued to be a source of comic brilliance until his final years.
content: Bob Newhart, who died on Thursday at the age of 94, has been such a beloved giant of popular culture for so long that it’s easy to forget how unlikely it was that he became one of the founding fathers of stand-up comedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Trump’s Misguided Fascination with Tariffs
description: Trump talks about how great William McKinley was for raising tariffs, but what worked in 1896 isn’t what works in 2024.
content: As the Republican Party repositions itself as the party of working men and women, William McKinley is having a moment. (I’m surprised, too.) McKinley, who served as president from 1897 to 1901, was such a champion of tariffs that he was happy to be called the Napoleon of Protection.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Boom Goes the Oil Industry Amid a Push for Clean Energy
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 19, 2024.
content: “People used to call us drunken sailors. Hopefully we’re shaking off that reputation now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: The White House Has a Plan to Slash Plastic Use in the U.S.
description: The government said it would phase out its purchases of single-use plastics, a significant step because it is the biggest buyer of consumer goods in the world.
content: Calling plastic pollution one of the world’s most pressing environmental problems, the Biden administration on Friday said that the federal government, the biggest buyer of consumer goods in the world, would phase out purchases of single-use plastics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 8 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
content: Directed by Lee Isaac Chung, this stand-alone follow-up to the 1996 blockbuster “Twister” stars Glen Powell as the cowboy-esque tornado wrangler Tyler Owens and Daisy Edgar-Jones as Kate Carter, a meteorologist who had a traumatic run-in with a tornado in her past. The two clash and then collaborate as they chase storms in Oklahoma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: White House Plan to Limit Rent Increases Nationwide Reignites Debate
description: A proposal to make landlords’ tax breaks contingent on rent limits has drawn industry pushback, progressive applause and some alternative approaches.
content: When the Biden administration laid out a suite of plans this week to address housing affordability, it added a bold update to previous proposals — and sent the housing industry and the economics world buzzing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: A Border Crossing Shuttered for Months Traps the Sick and Wounded in Gaza
description: The Rafah crossing to Egypt has been closed since Israel captured it in early May, blocking the only route out of the territory for thousands of Palestinians who desperately need medical care.
content: After months of waiting, Fida Ghanem was granted a permit by Israel and Egypt to leave Gaza for urgent lymphoma treatment in the spring. But the next morning, Israeli forces seized the only border crossing from Gaza to Egypt, in Rafah, as part of a military offensive against Hamas in the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Trump Can’t Help Himself. Will That Help Him Win?
description: The R.N.C. ended with uncertainty about whether Trump can capitalize on the opportunity ahead.
content: It was all going so well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat and Carlos Lozada
title: Trump Anoints Himself
description: So that’s what a post-assassination-attempt speech sounds like.
content: The former president was expected to offer unity in his nomination acceptance speech. But after a wild week, his speech revealed the same old Donald Trump. In this episode, the hosts debate: Is Trump a “man of destiny”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Melissa Clark Pantry Pasta to Greet the Weekend
description: We have all weekend for chan chan yaki and cheesy pan pizza. Friday night is for superquick pantry pasta with tuna, scallions and capers.
content: Good morning. It would be nice to cook a project recipe this weekend, to spend Saturday tending to a brisket softening in wood smoke out in the yard, or assembling a lane cake at my kitchen counter. I could set up some gravlax to cure all week, for next Sunday’s breakfast. I could make a timpano or roll up a platter of kimbap. There are so many possibilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Victor Moriyama
title: Is She the Oldest Person in the Amazon?
description: The life of Varî Vãti Marubo shows how much life has changed for the rainforest’s Indigenous tribes — and how much has stayed the same.
content: After more than 100 years in the rainforest, Varî Vãti Marubo walks with a stick and, as she always has, barefoot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derek M. Norman, Christine Chung and Ceylan Yeğinsu
title: Traveling Today? What You Need to Know About the Global Tech Outage.
description: While service is slowly recovering, flights are still being canceled and delays can stretch for hours. Here’s the latest on airlines, airports and cruises, as well as your rights and how to reach customer service.
content: While commercial air service was slowly recovering on Friday after a technology outage caused thousands of flights worldwide to be canceled or delayed, the ripple effect from the disruption left airports crowded with passengers and airlines working to get planes and crews back in position.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
description: The total hours Amtrak trains were delayed in fiscal year 2023
content: As the planet warms, train delays and breakdowns are becoming more frequent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: Black Democrats, Resisting Calls for Biden to Exit, Insist Harris is Only Alternative
description: Some Black Democrats are speaking out against what they see as a disregard for their voice as the party frets over Mr. Biden’s candidacy.
content: As President Biden faces mounting calls from within his own party to discontinue his re-election campaign, a group of Black Democrats is working to rally support for him — but also to send a firm message that Vice President Kamala Harris is the sole alternative to lead the ticket if he opts to withdraw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Jack Healy, Eduardo Medina, Campbell Robertson and J. David Goodman
title: What Undecided Voters Thought of Trump’s Speech: Mostly, Not Much
description: The former president did not win them over — not that they like the alternative.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump began his prime-time speech at the Republican National Convention on Thursday with a message of unity, presenting a softer image of himself that appeared aimed at courting undecided voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: Secret Service Director Will Testify Before Congress on Monday
description: It will be Kimberly A. Cheatle’s first appearance before lawmakers since the assassination attempt on former President Trump’s life.
content: The director of the Secret Service, Kimberly A. Cheatle, will appear before lawmakers for the first time on Monday as scrutiny intensifies over the security failures at the Pennsylvania rally where a gunman tried to kill former President Donald J. Trump, the agency announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Pacific Northwest Braces for a Blistering Heat Wave Over the Weekend
description: The heat index, an indicator of temperature and humidity, could reach triple digits, well above what is typical for the region.
content: A dangerous heat wave is expected to affect parts of the Pacific Northwest over the weekend in a region where authorities are still addressing the deadly impact of record-breaking temperatures in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Landon Nordeman and Alex Vadukul
title: Trump From Head to Toe
description: The Republican National Convention was a showcase for Donald J. Trump’s dominance over the party — and its fashion.
content: As the press corps descended on the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee this week, most photojournalists focused on the politicians and guest speakers who rallied the crowd night after night for former President Donald J. Trump. During his four days at the convention, Landon Nordeman, a photographer on assignment for the Styles desk of The New York Times, trained his lens mainly on the human spectacle away from the stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Happy Traum, Mainstay of the Folk Music World, Dies at 86
description: A noted guitarist and banjo player, he emerged from the same Greenwich Village folk-revival scene as his friend and sometime collaborator Bob Dylan.
content: Happy Traum, a celebrated folk singer, guitarist and banjo player who was a mainstay of the Greenwich Village coffeehouse scene of the early 1960s, recorded with Bob Dylan and had an influential career as a music instructor, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Healy
title: Trump Goes Off the Rails. This Guy Is Still Beatable.
description: His speech was thin on unity and heavy on the unhinged.
content: In my 20 years of covering presidential campaigns as a journalist, there have been just two political conventions where the presidential nominees, their teams, the delegates and the party spent all four days radiating the confidence of a winner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Paula Szuchman, Wendy Dorr, Marion Lozano, Melissa Kirsch and Pete Wells
title: Check, Please: The Pete Wells Exit Interview
description: Why our food critic tossed the fake glasses and quit his dream job.
content: Pete Wells announced on Tuesday that he was stepping down as The Times’s restaurant critic. Wells became the restaurant critic in 2012, and his insights into the dining experience, alongside his biting wit, have made him a favorite of our readers. But recent health issues have caused him to reconsider his relationship with dining out. Wells joins Melissa Kirsch, the deputy editor of Culture and Lifestyle for The Times, to discuss why he’s leaving his post, the highs and lows of his life as a critic, and what he hopes for the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: The Data That Powers A.I. Is Disappearing Fast
description: New research from the Data Provenance Initiative has found a dramatic drop in content made available to the collections used to build artificial intelligence.
content: For years, the people building powerful artificial intelligence systems have used enormous troves of text, images and videos pulled from the internet to train their models.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Qasim Nauman
title: Cheng Pei Pei, ‘Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon’ Star, Dies at 78
description: A trailblazer for women in Asian martial arts cinema, Ms. Cheng rose to fame in the 1960s in Hong Kong.
content: Cheng Pei Pei, a trailblazer for women in Asian martial arts cinema and a star of the 2000 blockbuster “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,” died on July 17 in the San Francisco Bay Area. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lana Bortolot
title: $800,000 Homes in Venice
description: A duplex near the Rialto Bridge, a one-bedroom in the Castello district, and a compact house on the island of Giudecca.
content: Called Ca’ Zorzi, so named for the noble family that once lived here, this “Piano Nobile” is well located in Venice’s historic center, near the Giardini Papadopoli, Rialto Bridge and the Rialto Market, and the 13th-century church of San Giacomo dall’Orio, founded in the ninth century. Nearby is the Ospedale vaporetto (the public water bus) on Fondamenta Nuove and the Santa Lucia train terminal, one of two stations serving Venice. The palazzo is a quarter mile from Piazzale Roma, the entrance to the city just across Constitution pedestrian bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: The Roots of Biden’s Defiance: Anger, Fear, Pride and Regret
description: President Biden is still bitter about feeling pushed out of the 2016 race by Democratic elites in favor of Hillary Clinton.
content: The seeds of President Biden’s reaction to the Democratic Party’s crisis of confidence in him were planted years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Theodore Schleifer
title: Michael Moritz, Democratic Megadonor, Urges Biden Exit: ‘Clock Has Run Out’
description: Mr. Moritz became one of the party’s top contributors to go public with his fears about the president’s candidacy, saying that Mr. Biden had a choice: “vanity or virtue.”
content: Michael Moritz, the billionaire Silicon Valley venture capitalist and a top Democratic donor, is calling for President Biden to step aside, becoming one of the party’s largest contributors to go public with his concerns about the president’s candidacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David C. Adams and James Wagner
title: At Least 40 Migrants Die in Boat Fire Off Haitian Coast, U.N. Says
description: The boat was carrying over 80 people and bound for Turks and Caicos. The disaster underscores the gang-fueled crisis that has spurred many Haitians to leave.
content: At least 40 migrants were killed when a boat they were traveling on from Haiti caught fire, a United Nations agency announced on Friday. The boat, which was carrying over 80 people, left the northern coast of Haiti on Wednesday en route for the Turks and Caicos Islands 150 miles away, the agency said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabby Sobelman, Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman, Lara Jakes and Erin Mendell
title: Houthis Launch Deadly Drone Strike on Tel Aviv, Evading Israel’s Defenses
description: At least one person was killed and eight others injured in a predawn attack on Friday. The Israeli military said it was investigating why it “did not identify it, attack it and intercept it.”
content: In a rare breach of Israel’s multilayered air-defense system, a drone fired by the Houthi militia in Yemen slammed into an apartment building near the United States Embassy branch office in Tel Aviv early Friday, killing at least one person and wounding eight others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick T. Brown
title: Pro-Lifers Helped Bring Trump to Power. Why Has He Abandoned Us?
description: Roe is history, but abortion hasn’t ended.
content: I am far from the only young conservative whose interest in politics was sparked by the issue of abortion. In high school and college, we would stake out early-morning spots on the National Mall for the annual March for Life, write postcards to our elected officials and pray rosaries outside abortion clinics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Tommy Robinson, Colorful Arkansas Sheriff and Congressman, Dies at 82
description: He gained national attention for his unorthodox approaches to policing in Little Rock and then went on to win three terms in the House of Representatives.
content: Tommy Robinson, who over two terms as a county sheriff in Arkansas in the 1980s made repeated national headlines with stunts like chaining inmates to a prison tower to protest jail overcrowding, and who then used that reputation to win three terms in Congress, died on July 10 in Forrest City, Ark., east of Little Rock. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk and Maya King
title: ‘Trumpmania’: Hulk Hogan Rips Off His Shirt, and Republicans Go Wild
description: The theatrical former professional wrestler flexed his muscles — and electrified the crowd — with an impassioned account of how he came to support the former president.
content: Hulk Hogan, the theatrical former professional wrestler, teed up former President Donald J. Trump on Thursday at the Republican National Convention with a rousing speech in which he ripped off his suit jacket and shirt, revealing a red Trump-Vance tank top to raucous cheers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Read the Transcript of Donald J. Trump’s Convention Speech
description: He spoke for just over 90 minutes.
content: Thank you very much. Thank you very, very much. And thank you, Dana. Thank you, Kid Rock, sometimes referred to as “Bob.” And thank you, Lee, right from the beginning, thank you very much. What a talent. What a beautiful, beautiful song. Thank you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 7: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by July 26 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced by Aug. 7.
content: Welcome to the seventh week of our 15th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Michael C. Bender
title: Trump Struggles to Turn the Page on ‘American Carnage’
description: On the last night of the G.O.P. convention on Thursday, Donald J. Trump promised to bridge political divides, and then returned to delighting in deepening them.
content: Donald J. Trump has long been a man undone by himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: At ‘Slave Play’ in London, a ‘Black Out’ Night Emerges From Controversy
description: Critics slammed the idea of “restricting audiences on the basis of race,” but at a recent performance, Black spectators praised producers for creating a safe space.
content: Elaine Grant was pleased with the scene unfolding outside the Noël Coward Theater in London on Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Danielle Kaye
title: What We Know About the Global Microsoft Outage
description: Airlines to banks to retailers were affected in many countries. Businesses are struggling to recover.
content: Across the world, critical businesses and services including airlines, hospitals, train networks and TV stations, were disrupted on Friday by a global tech outage affecting Microsoft users.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: Fact-Checking the Immigration Chart That Trump Says ‘Saved My Life’
description: Donald J. Trump escaped an assassination attempt with only an ear wound after he turned to show a graphic, which he again highlighted at the R.N.C. But the facts on immigration are misleading.
content: Donald J. Trump, while accepting the Republican nomination for president on Thursday, displayed an immigration graphic that he credited with saving his life during an assassination attempt at a rally in Pennsylvania days earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: A Chameleon’s Dance at Little Island
description: Pam Tanowitz’s “Day for Night” flows with and against the current of its surroundings, reflecting the park’s strange mix of the natural and man-made.
content: In the work of the choreographer Pam Tanowitz, it’s not uncommon for dancers to match the space around them, dressed to blend with their environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Salmonella Sickened 171, the Biggest Outbreak From Raw Milk in Years
description: Experts say the number of people affected in the outbreak, linked to Raw Farm milk, could be far higher.
content: When Jackie’s 9-year-old son came down with a low-grade fever in October, she chalked it up to a typical back-to-school bug. But his illness worsened over the next couple of days. “His skin tone looked gray,” she said, and near-constant diarrhea left him unable to sleep and too weak to stand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin Counted on Waning U.S. Interest in Ukraine. It Might Be a Winning Bet.
description: The arc of American foreign policy could be moving closer to the Russian president’s view of it. But he has been wrong before about the U.S.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin’s strategy for defeating Ukraine can be summed up in one revealing moment in his February interview with the former television host Tucker Carlson. Addressing the possibility of heightened U.S. involvement in Ukraine, the Russian leader asked Americans: “Don’t you have anything better to do?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Jun Michael Park
title: Why Do Kind Strangers Return Our Wallets?
description: Whoever you are, we appreciate it.
content: Dear Anonymous Kind Stranger Who Didn’t Include a Return Address:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Sharks Don’t Sink. And Neither Does She.
description: In a new memoir, the marine biologist Jasmin Graham reflects on her passion for studying sharks and the barriers she refused to let stop her.
content: Jasmin Graham was on a mission. The marine biologist wanted to change not only the public’s often misleading perception of sharks — in many cases, drawn from their harrowing portrayal in the novel “Jaws” and calcified in pop culture over the last 50 years — but also that of the people who study them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Group Urging Biden to Exit Race Aims Ads for ‘Morning Joe’
description: Ads saying, “Pass the torch,” are set to air next week in Washington and in Rehoboth Beach, Del., where Mr. Biden is isolating after testing positive for Covid.
content: A Democratic group urging President Biden not to seek re-election is working to take that message to him directly in the coming days, releasing a new ad set to air on MSNBC, including on “Morning Joe,” which Mr. Biden is known to watch regularly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Eve Sampson
title: Isolation and Secrecy: What We Know About Russia’s Notorious Penal Colonies
description: Evan Gershkovich, The Wall Street Journal reporter, was convicted on fabricated charges and is expected to serve time in one of the country’s infamous prisons.
content: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, was convicted of espionage in Russia on Friday and sentenced to 16 years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Reid J. Epstein, Jonathan Swan, Clare Toeniskoetter, Carlos Prieto, Rob Szypko, Alex Stern, Rachel Quester, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker and Alyssa Moxley
title: At the Republican Convention, Trump Achieves Mythical Status
description: While the Republican Party united under former President Donald J. Trump, the Democratic Party has been scrambling.
content: Donald J. Trump’s acceptance of his party’s nomination put an exclamation point on a triumphant week for a Republican Party that emerged from its convention confident and unified. At the same time, the Democratic Party is moving closer and closer to replacing President Biden on the ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Trump the Lion, or Trump the Lyin’?
description: After years on a self-mythologizing hero’s journey, the former president finally had a true story to tell.
content: No one has ever said that Donald Trump doesn’t know a good story when he hears one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Biden Administration Pauses Student Loan Payments Amid Legal Challenges
description: Eight million borrowers enrolled in the repayment plan known as SAVE will be placed in an interest-free forbearance while the administration deals with legal issues.
content: The Biden administration is pausing student loan payments for eight million borrowers enrolled in its new repayment plan, known as SAVE, after a federal appellate court issued a ruling temporarily blocking the program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Friday Briefing
description: A pivotal moment in the White House race.
content: The U.S. presidential race has reached a pivotal moment. Donald Trump formally accepted the Republican nomination last night in an arena packed with supporters. His opponent, President Biden, is currently isolating with Covid-19 and, according to people in his inner circle, wrestling with whether to drop out of the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Zelensky Becomes First Foreign Leader to Visit U.K. Cabinet Since Clinton
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky briefed Keir Starmer’s top team in an appearance designed to showcase Britain’s steadfast support for Ukraine in its war against Russia.
content: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, became the first foreign leader to attend Britain’s cabinet meeting in person since former U.S. president Bill Clinton in 1997, in a public display of Britain’s staunch support for Ukraine as doubts grow about future U.S. military aid if Donald J. Trump wins a second presidential term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How the Global Tech Outage Disrupted Airlines, Subways and More
description: See how chaotic moments played out on Friday.
content: From Manila to the Netherlands and New Jersey, critical businesses and services were brought to a standstill on Friday by a global tech outage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, Glenn Thrush and William K. Rashbaum
title: Gunman Might Have Scoped Out Site Six Days Before Trump Rally
description: The would-be assassin also had a bulletproof jacket in his car that he did not wear when he opened fire on the former president, along with several magazines for a rifle.
content: Federal investigators are examining the possibility that a would-be assassin scoped out the area where former President Donald J. Trump was to speak six days before the campaign rally in Pennsylvania where Mr. Trump was wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: They Wanted Marriage and Family, Maybe Not in That Order
description: Traci Green and Christopher Sater set their own relationship timeline after meeting through a dating app seven years ago.
content: In the summer of 2023, Christopher William Sater and Traci Ryan Green hosted a combined engagement party and baby shower. “The theme was ‘Engaged and Expecting,’” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Deadly Protests Grip Bangladesh
description: Students, armed mainly with sticks, have been demonstrating for days against a quota system for government jobs they consider unfair. Dozens have died in the violence.
content: For days, university students in Bangladesh have been locked in deadly clashes with the police and supporters of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina’s party, in which dozens of people have been killed and more than 1,000 injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Lady in the Lake’ Review: Not Just Another Baltimore Mystery
description: Natalie Portman stars in an elaborate adaptation of Laura Lippman’s novel about a pair of 1960s murders.
content: If you’ve read Laura Lippman’s novel “Lady in the Lake,” about a pair of murders in Baltimore in the 1960s, you will know right away that the Apple TV+ mini-series based on it has taken liberties. The Thanksgiving parade that opens the action is not in the book; neither is the man dressed as a mailbox whom we see relieving himself in an alley before resuming his place in the procession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Kim Deal Goes Solo, and 7 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Alan Sparhawk, Joy Oladokun, Ivan Cornejo and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Bobby Grier, Who Integrated the Sugar Bowl in 1956, Dies at 91
description: The governor of Georgia tried to ban him from the game, but the state’s Board of Regents let him play. ‘Stupid. Why did the governor have to jump into sports?’ Grier asked years later.
content: Bobby Grier, a University of Pittsburgh fullback who in 1956 became the first Black football player to take the field in the postseason Sugar Bowl in New Orleans, despite the opposition of Georgia’s segregationist governor, who sought to bar Georgia Tech, Pitt’s opponent, from playing in the game, died on June 30 in Warren, Ohio. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kay Bloomberg
title: I Said He Could, So He Did
description: If you give your partner permission to sleep with someone else, he might take that as permission to leave.
content: Being left for a younger woman is a time-honored tradition in my family. When my mother was 2, her father began a string of extramarital adventures and ended his marriage to my grandmother, starting a feud that lasted decades and tore their family apart. But my grandfather and his second wife were married for 49 years, so perhaps it was for the best.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Russia Punishes Those Who Seek the Truth
description: Evan Gershkovich is a victim of Putin’s campaign to silence independent journalism in Russia.
content: The only surprise in the guilty verdict against Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal correspondent who was arrested in Russia last year on phony charges of espionage, was that it came so quickly. The charge itself was a farce. No evidence was ever made public, the hearings were held in secret, and Mr. Gershkovich’s lawyers were barred from saying anything in public about the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabby Sobelman, Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon, Rawan Sheikh Ahmad and Erin Mendell
title: Israel’s military says it’s investigating why it missed the drone that hit Tel Aviv.
description: An Israeli military official said the military was still investigating where the drone was launched from.
content: The Iran-backed Houthi militia claimed responsibility for a rare drone attack in central Tel Aviv that crashed into a building near the United States Embassy branch office early Friday, killing at least one person and wounding eight others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: The Stomach-Dropping, Heart-Tugging Appeal of Climbing Documentaries
description: “Skywalkers” and “Mountain Queen” are strong entries in a genre with great appeal to viewers who themselves might prefer to be sitting.
content: Documentaries in which people climb very tall things have a remarkable track record. “Man on Wire,” James Marsh’s 2008 recounting of Philippe Petit’s high-wire walk between the Twin Towers in 1974, is one of the most acclaimed and successful documentaries of all time. Jimmy Chin and Chai Vasarhelyi have made two celebrated films about the sport, “Meru” in 2015 and “Free Solo” in 2018. Just do a quick search for “climbing documentaries” and you’ll find dozens — it’s clearly a genre people love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers
title: Secluded in Rehoboth, Biden Stews at Allies’ Pressure to Drop Out of the Race
description: As he recovers from Covid, the president has grown resentful toward Democratic congressional leaders and former President Barack Obama.
content: Sick with Covid and abandoned by allies, President Biden has been fuming at his Delaware beach house, increasingly resentful about what he sees as an orchestrated campaign to drive him out of the race and bitter toward some of those he once considered close, including his onetime running mate Barack Obama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: To Sell Prized Paintings, a University Proclaims They’re Not ‘Conservative’
description: Valparaiso University is arguing it should never have acquired two paintings, including a Georgia O’Keeffe, in the 1960s. It hopes to sell them to pay for dorm renovations.
content: What makes a painting conservative?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Democratic Officials Urge Committee to Nominate Biden Through Virtual Vote
description: The officials also said the virtual roll call should not happen before Aug. 1. The rules committee for the party convention will vote on the matter next week.
content: Top Democratic Party officials on Friday urged the Democratic National Convention’s rules committee to choose to nominate President Biden through a virtual roll call vote rather than on the convention floor, as Mr. Biden continues to lose support from Democrats about whether he should be on the ticket at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein and Sarah Blesener
title: She Danced Naked at Woodstock. She Dated Serpico. At 93, She’s Not Done.
description: Betty Gordon came to New York to become an actress (and have a good time). But her greatest talent may have been helping others.
content: Betty Gordon is perhaps the world’s most unlikely first-time children’s book author.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Canada Pledges to Meet NATO Spending Goal. It Won’t Be Easy.
description: The country’s struggle to reach an informal military spending target highlights how difficult it is for the alliance to quickly bolster its abilities.
content: Long seen as punching below its weight, Canada, the world’s second-largest country by area and one of its seven wealthiest economies, said it would meet its NATO pledge to significantly bolster its military spending by 2032.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Whitney Jones, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Chris Wood, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
title: Social Media Reacts to an Attempted Assassination; Tech Elites for Trump; and TikTok’s Jawmaxxing Trend
description: “The 2024 internet is just different than the internet we lived on four years ago.”
content: This week, an assassination attempt for the social media age: what the platforms got right and wrong in the chaotic aftermath. Then we talk with the Times reporter Teddy Schleifer from this week’s Republican National Convention in Milwaukee about the wave of Silicon Valley billionaires stepping up to back Trump. And finally, we talk to The Times’s Styles reporter Callie Holtermann about facial fitness gum, a “jawmaxxing” product targeted at teen boys online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Steve Eder, William K. Rashbaum, Amy Julia Harris, Jack Healy and Glenn Thrush
title: From Honor Student to the Gunman Who Tried to Kill Donald Trump
description: Thomas Crooks was a brainy and quiet young man who built computers and won honors at school, impressing his teachers. Then he became a would-be assassin.
content: For Thomas Crooks, the suburban Pittsburgh nursing home where he served meals and washed dishes for $16 an hour was another solitary corner of a nearly invisible life. He was polite but distant, a former co-worker said, ate lunch alone in the break room and rarely spoke with anyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Do You View Self-Care as You Age?
description: We want to hear about what taking care of yourself while getting older means to you.
content: How do you care for your body as you get older? Do you use nutrition, meditation or hobbies like swimming or dancing to help you reset? What we see in the mirror as we get older can bring joy, tumult or simply an opportunity to acknowledge the passing of time. So we want to hear from you about the things you do for health, vanity or fun to help us understand what aging looks and feels like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: What Presidential Election? So Far, the Stock Market Doesn’t Care.
description: Traders appear to be focused on possible Fed rate cuts and corporate earnings, and are remarkably indifferent to political fortunes, our columnist says.
content: With the Republican Convention behind us, the Trump-Vance ticket is the favorite in polls and in markets where you can predict the winner of the presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Six Takeaways From the Republican Convention
description: Donald J. Trump ended a buoyant gathering in Milwaukee with a speech that started solemn, turned rambling and showcased his all-encompassing power over his party.
content: Donald J. Trump’s dramatic acceptance of his party’s nomination just days after a failed assassination attempt put an exclamation point on a triumphant week for a Republican Party that emerged from its convention confident and unified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Which Weight Loss Drug Should You Choose (if You Get to Choose)?
description: As patients consider drugs like Wegovy, Ozempic, Zepbound and Mounjaro to treat obesity, experts say the choices are not so simple.
content: People with obesity now have a choice between two powerful drugs to help them lose weight. One is semaglutide, sold by Novo Nordisk as Wegovy for obesity treatment and as Ozempic for diabetes. The second, tirzepatide, is sold by Eli Lilly as Zepbound for obesity and as Mounjaro for diabetes. Many with neither obesity or diabetes take the drugs to get thinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Teamsters Leader’s Speech to Republicans Still Reverberates
description: Sean O’Brien delivered one of the most memorable addresses to the convention, calling out corporations and business groups as anti-worker. It’s divided union leaders.
content: Of the dozens of speeches at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, none perhaps was as surprising — or as immediately divisive— as Teamsters President Sean O’Brien’s on the conclave’s first night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Soller
title: In Paris, an Apartment With Views That Look Like Postcards
description: A design duo transformed part of a historic building into a home that foregrounds the city’s splendor.
content: Unlike, say, Milan or New York, Paris isn’t a city that hides its beauty behind closed doors. Most of the French capital’s grand boulevards are, of course, lined with Haussmannian buildings, their stone facades and wrought-iron balconies as elegant as the herringbone parquet floors and marble fireplaces inside. Traditionally, because residents had to ascend these 19th-century buildings using narrow stairways, at least until the arrival of elevators, the second and third levels were the most desirable, with grander proportions and classical layouts. The sixth floor, known for its angular zinc roofline, was reserved for chambres de bonne (maid’s quarters), compact single rooms in which domestic staff once lived and which now might be rented to study-abroad students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Rebuilt Monastery, Aided by Beer Sales, Gives Hope to a Quake-Struck Region
description: Eight years after devastating earthquakes ravaged central Italy, the reopening of a monastery is an inspiration for an area still struggling to recover.
content: They may have chosen a contemplative life of prayer, detached from world affairs, but last month a small community of Benedictine monks threw a very big bash for the opening of their new monastery on a hill overlooking the central Italian town of Norcia, where St. Benedict was born.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Accepting the Republican Nomination, Trump Preaches Unity, Then Reverts to Attacks
description: Donald J. Trump, closing a convention that had sought to soften his image and portray him as the leader of an inclusive movement, began with a sober retelling of an assassination attempt but pivoted to grudges and vilifying Democrats.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump accepted the Republican presidential nomination for the third time on Thursday night with a speech that opened with a somber appeal to unity before reverting to a divisive and rambling list of grievances and attacks on his political opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kieran Press-Reynolds
title: Rage and Fury Make These Diabolical Games Easy to Watch
description: One slip-up is devastating in Chained Together, The Game of Sisyphus and A Difficult Game About Climbing. That’s what makes them so compelling on livestreams.
content: A swarm of new video games is channeling anxiety as an aesthetic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: Large Earthquake Rocks Northern Chile
description: There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage after the 7.4 magnitude earthquake.
content: A 7.4 magnitude earthquake struck northern Chile on Thursday. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi, Derrick Bryson Taylor and Corey Kilgannon
title: Airlines Restart Flights but Disruptions are Expected to Persist
description: Planes began taking off again Friday morning after a big tech outage, but it will take airlines a while to get stranded passengers to their destinations.
content: Airlines raced on Friday to contain the effects of a tech outage that severely disrupted travel around the world early in the day, delaying or stranding passengers and flight crews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Britain says it’s restoring funding to the U.N. agency that aids Palestinians.
description: The country’s new foreign secretary said that the agency, UNRWA, had taken steps to ensure that it meets “the highest standards of neutrality.”
content: Britain said on Friday that it would restore funding to the United Nations agency for Palestinians, a major vote of confidence in the embattled aid group by the country’s new Labour government in its first significant move on the Israel-Gaza conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Evan Gershkovich Sentenced to 16 Years in Russian Prison on Fabricated Charges
description: The Wall Street Journal reporter’s trial on espionage charges was widely viewed as a sham outside Russia. But the verdict could set the stage for a prisoner exchange.
content: A court in Russia on Friday sentenced Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, to 16 years in a high-security penal colony, ending his espionage trial on what were widely viewed outside Russia as fabricated charges. The verdict opens the way for a potential prisoner swap between the United States and Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Kate Conger
title: What to Do if Your Computer Is Affected by the Microsoft Outage
description: A massive outage related to a security update by CrowdStrike, a cybersecurity company, crippled airlines and other businesses on Friday.
content: An outage that crippled businesses around the world turned many Microsoft computers into bricks overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: credo
description: This word has appeared in 45 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word credo has appeared in 45 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 19 in “New York’s First Black Librarians Changed the Way We Read” by Jennifer Schuessler:
